Hence, livid Envy, murkiest fiend of hell,</br>Hence, blood-stain'd Malice, to thy baleful cell;</br>Avaunt, and shed not here your venom'd rage,</br>Nor with your touch pollute the sacred page;</br>To MASON the melodious lays belong,</br>MASON, the soul of genius and of song!

Hail, bard sublime, with raptur'd eyes we see</br>The soul of Sophocles reviv'd in thee;</br>Hail, wond'rous youth!  in whose bright strains conspire</br>Plato's cool judgment, and warm Pindar's fire;</br>Whilst Homer's grandeur, Virgil's sweetness join,</br>To make each noble sentiment divine.

What grief, that scenes, which in an earlier age</br>Had won the wreath on Athen's polish'd stage;</br>Those scenes produc'd beneath bright learning's throne,</br>Which Delpho's god without a blush might own;</br>Those scenes where fire-fraught fancy's strongest ray</br>Adorns and animates the moral lay;</br>What grief, that scenes like these, by wayward chance,</br>Must yield to pantomime, or paultry dance?</br>While the true Attic elegance and wit,</br>Dare hope no plaudit from a British pit.

What is th' applause of a theatric crowd!</br>The breath of folly, by caprice bestow'd.</br>A soul like thine disdains such trivial praise,</br>Nor seeks to mount to fame by vulgar ways;</br>Nobly content with modest merit's due,</br>The just applause for ever shall be thine,</br>And thro' all ages thy Elfrida shine;</br>Elfrida's still shall live with MASON'S name,</br>Distinguish'd in the brightest rolls of fame.</br>
